awd_titl_txt: Actualizing STEM Potential in the Mississippi Delta
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by investigating the effectiveness of an existing collaborative robotics program. The program will positively influence the engineering self-efficacy and orientation to STEM majors with African American students living in an underserved region of the United States, the Mississippi Delta.  Students in this program are immersed in engineering design activities requiring the application of science and mathematics principles.  The program model includes pre-engineering courses in computer science, computer aided drafting, and electronics. These are designed and facilitated by university faculty. Undergraduate seniors are trained by faculty and then serve as mentors. Engineering design activities, career orientation activities and robotics summer camps for elementary and middle school students are facilitated by high school faculty.  At the beginning of the spring semester, students participate in an international robotics competition.  This robotics program is year-long and occurs after school, and halfway through the year students enter their designs in a robotics competition.  Beginning in the freshmen year, students are allowed to remain in the program throughout their years in high school. An understanding of the components that positively influence the African American students' beliefs about their abilities in STEM disciplines and their perceptions of their identification with STEM could be useful for understanding and decreasing the gap in STEM majors that exists with students from underserved populations in the United States.  

This longitudinal mixed methods research study is designed to investigate the influence of engineering design and career orientation activities implemented in a collaborative robotics/pre-engineering program on African American students' self-efficacy, and scientific identity, to better understand factors influencing their achievement in STEM disciplines and orientation to STEM majors.  This is a four year study, allowing the researchers to follow a group of students from freshman to the end of their senior year, so that key factors influencing the students' learning and achievement in the engineering course activities can be observed and documented during the peak years of decision making for college majors and careers.  This study is unique in terms of its location and population of students, and because it is longitudinal and utilizes a mixed methods approach.   While this study investigates the effectiveness of the program on the engineering self-efficacy, scientific identity and achievement of program objectives for students in this program, the findings of the study could also be valuable for informing initiatives devoted to increasing the numbers of students from other marginalized groups majoring in STEM fields. Quantitatively, this research employs pre and post measures to determine changes in students engineering self-efficacy and scientific identities.   Qualitatively, field notes from classroom observations and interviews with the high school students provide data on specific program elements determined to be effective in positively influencing the African American students' achievement of program objectives and decisions to pursue STEM careers.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
A successful public school/university robotics collaborative project integrated with participation in the FIRST Robotics Competition was replicated in a socioeconomically deprived school district in the Mississippi Delta. The goal of this project was to mitigate social disparities contributing to inequitable access to STEM education experiences for students in this region by immersing them in learning experiences that supported them in realizing their potential in STEM. In this project, minoritized students in grades 9-12 were engaged in inquiry-based activities integrated with engineering applications, designed to enhance their self-efficacies and science identities. The objective was to provide access to STEM education, physically through exposure to adequate resources, and socially by fostering identity transformation through sustained engagement stemming from multi-year participation. The project targeted 33 students each year, with new students added as graduates exited the program. Nearly all students who enrolled in the first year of the project in grades 9-11 remained in the project throughout their high school years, resulting in a 90% retention rate. A learning progression outlining curricular goals for achieving self-efficacy and science identity outcomes for marginalized students was developed in this project.

 

This project was successful in achieving its intended goals and objectives.  The longitudinal mixed methods research for this project examined changes in students? self-efficacy and science identity across the four years of the program, with particular focus on students who entered as freshman and remained throughout the four years.  For the quantitative analysis, paired sample t-tests for pre/post tests were conducted for the two surveys, Attitude Toward Science Inventory (ATSI) and Longitudinal Assessment of Engineering Self Efficacy (LAESE).  Longitudinal data for the ATSI survey indicated statistical significance (p < 0.05) substantiating that the students? participation in the curricular activities enhanced their conceptions of their identity with science. Additionally, longitudinal data for the LAESE survey indicated statistical significance (p < 0.05) substantiating that the students? self-efficacy was enhanced from their participation in the curricular activities.  

 

Qualitatively, the research findings corroborated the quantitative results, highlighting components from the project?s robotics program that the students indicated as influential to their development. From the analysis of the interviews, it was determined that repeated successful experiences with the inquiry engineering design curricular activities, as well as the successful completion of the robot for the robotics competitions enhanced students? self-efficacy and science identity. The affirming instructional strategies supported students in actualizing agency and independence related to self-guided learning, evidencing the development of a science identity.  Transformations in the students? identity were attributed to the project?s multiyear design as evidenced by veteran students? requests for more challenging independent projects that required them to research new applications and learn new skills. Additionally, the students demonstrated growth in their leadership skills which was evidenced by them volunteering to teach in the summer pipeline robotics camps for upper elementary and middle school students, and in conducting robot demonstrations at local elementary and middle schools. This growth in leadership was also evidenced in the occasional recommendations that veteran students would share for improving the experiences for new students entering the program.  

 

Conclusively, the classroom environment existed as a counter space for students, in that meeting the high expectations evidenced their capacity to be contributors in STEM, subtly opposing society?s messaging portraying them as inferior.  Students? consciousness of the impact of deficit narratives was evidenced in their statements regarding disproving stereotypical intimations through their achievement of curricular goals, which they regarded as a victory. 

 

Curricular units consisting of inquiry-based activities integrated with engineering design were developed each year of the program. STEM summer camp activities were also developed each year for students in grades 3-8 and were successful in piquing students? interest in STEM and also existed as a source of motivation for them enrolling in the high school program. To date, approximately 120 students participated in this project. Alumni data collected to date indicates 40% of the students went to college and majored in STEM fields, and approximately 50% of those students majored in fields related to robotics. The overall success of this project inspired the school district?s commitment to sustain it. 

 

Additional outcomes for the project include an effective university/public school collaborative model which positioned seniors from the university as mentors to high school students in the spring semesters during the competition phase of the project.  Curriculum was developed for the mentoring and managerial structure and process for university students that were engaged in mentoring high school students at the public school site. The curriculum modules developed and facilitated by the university faculty in computer programming, computer aided design and electronics were effective in introducing students to fundamental knowledge about robotics. Lastly, the high school robotics program model integrated with the robotics competition was effective in introducing students to the application of engineering knowledge and skills for problem solving and innovation.  

 

 


Last Modified: 09/20/2022
Modified by: Brenda R Brand
